title: Milestone of Aurelius Cotta
support: The original block, of the local stone, is said to have been approximately 1.5 m tall, with a maximum width of 0.46m and depth of 0.33m (so Di Vita 1955). However only two fragments are preserved (it having been broken up on discovery), both set into cement: the upper fragment (1), being max W 42 cm, max H 38 cm (face 33 cm), max D 36 cm; the lower fragment (2) is max W 32 cm, max H 27 cm across the face; the depth is uncertain, being only a piece off the front of the stone, now set into cement. A fragment is clearly missing from the left side, equivalent to a couple of letters, but the right side of the upper fragment appears original, and the top may well be also, both roughly finished.

handNote.lettering: Deep and well carved, with a U-shaped cut letters of generally regular height. Most letters are c.75mm tall; O is consistently smaller than the other letters (55-60 mm), S taller at 95 mm, and the numeral 50 is 110 mm. A deep round interpunct is viisble at the end of line 3.

provenanceFound._: Found in contrada Zuccarone, to the East of modern Corleone, by farm-workers on the southern side of a trackway (overall running north-south, but bending east-west at this specific point). Now on display in the Corleone Museo Civico.

facsimile.desc: Photo J. Prag, 2023.10.28, courtesy Museo Civico di Corleone.

museum.name: Museo Civico Pippo Rizzo
museum.description: Arranged across 2 floors and a series of rooms, the upper floor follows a chronological arrangement beginning with the Neolithic and Bronze Age, the 5-4 century BC site of Montagna Vecchia, then some Hellenistic and Roman finds (including the famous milestone). The lower floor is a lapidarium with some reconstructed pithoi. Several columns and architrave pieces come from 2 Roman peristyle houses
